response.answer_text: When it comes to teach coding to 6-year olds, people generally have a weird misconception about it. They often relate it with something really high-tech and consider it too much of a burden for their toddlers. They think that their children’s shoulders already carry too much of a workload to handle learning a programming language which is based on an older generation’s mindset. I recently got my sister enrolled in WhiteHat Jr. After almost half a year later, I can proudly boost about the changes I have seen in her and how much her creative capacity has grown given her current age of 8 years. When I first came across WhiteHat Jr’s. advertisement, I got a bit intrigued by the fact that they were successfully teaching coding children ranging from the ages of 6 to 14. Given the situation of pandemic, my family was looking for an extra-curricular activity for my sister to keep her occupied. Thus, this seemed like an interesting opportunity. We booked a demo class which they were offering at absolutely no cost. The tutor was so well-versed with the curriculum and suggested what would be best for the toddler after having a one-to-one conversation with her. The sent us all the details of what all the course included, how and when the classes were going to be conducted, number of classes, etc to keep us included in the loop. Now, mainly because of the outstanding one-to-one sessions offered by them, I can honestly see the change in my sister. The way her creative thinking has improved and the increased confidence she displays now is something the entire family is proud of. Instead of beginning with really difficult coding languages, they begin their courses with easy and fun drag and drop commands which immediately widens the smile on the toddler’s face. The innovative way of using badges and beautiful hats to make the weekly and monthly assignments interesting not only gets the kids to enjoy these tasks but also creates a bit of competitiveness. The 21st century is the century of technology and WhiteHat Jr. is ensuring the next generation is fully prepared to make the most of it.

WhiteHat Jr. is actually for kids between 6 and 14 years old. Simply put, this is for children to learn coding – which is a very broad subject and can take years to master. So if you start them young, which is exactly what I did for my son, then your child can be a master coder within just a few years. What I like about WhiteHat Jr. is how they divided the courses from beginner to professional levels. Depending on your child’s age and skill level, he can enroll in a coding course and advance through the years. It is not rushed and WhiteHat Jr. doesn’t give out all the info and lessons to students in just one huge file or session. Teaching happens gradually so there’s no information overload. This means that even if your child has zero idea on how coding works, he will eventually learn and become a master. When you look at their curriculum on their website, you will see that it is divided into 4 different categories: beginner (grade 1), intermediate (grades 2-3), advanced (grades 4-6), and professional (grades 7-9). The category levels are quite self-explanatory so you shouldn’t have any problems with that. They do have a free trial, which has limited slots only. During the free trial, your child can experience first-hand what happens during teaching sessions, which is typically 1:1 – 1 child to 1 instructor. During the free trial, I was monitoring my child and the teacher also, and it seemed like the teacher was really an expert in this field. I chose WhiteHat Jr. for my child because they specialize in online coding lessons. While other online schools for kids offer a variety of other subjects, WhiteHat focuses on coding, which is one of the top deciding factors for me. And since we all know that everything that happens on the Internet changes over time, I feel like, with this focused coding study they offer, they will continually update their lessons depending on the changes that happen in the coding world real-time.

I think I can better answer your question since I have enrolled my cousin in Whitehat jr 4 months back. Let me tell you that I took free trial session before paying for the actual course. My cousin is 10 years old and he had no prior idea about coding before he started learning from Whitehat jr. Before starting about the course structure, I would like to give you a brief about Whitehat jr. Whitehat jr is a Mumbai based Ed-tech company founded by Karan Bajaj. He is the former head of Discovery Networks and currently serving as the CEO of the Company. Whitehat jr focuses on teaching coding to kids aged between 6-14 years via live classes of 45-minutes. How Whitehat jr curriculum is structured: 1. Beginner level: This course is mainly designed for grade 1 students. It covers the concept of commands, loops and conditions(If-else statements). Kids can be able to design board games from this course. 2. Intermediate level: It is created for students of class 2 and class 3. It comprises of algorithms, patterns, recognition and abstraction. It teaches the skills required to develop characters and animations. 3. Advanced level: It is for students studying in standard 4, 5 and 6. It teaches about variables, events as well as UI design. It enables students to design games and apps. 4. Professional level: This course is designed for grade 7, 8 and 9 students. It includes game design, design thinking, UI/UX, data science. With this course, students can develop and design games and apps having better graphics and interfaces. You can visit their website for more details: Live Online Coding for Kids | WhiteHat Jr.

Create a Special Environment for Students and Faculty Your institution and program offerings define your platform’s unique learning experience. Online programs must show the distinctive characteristics of the faculty, student community, and the university for students to feel as though they belong to it. Your online platform should capture the essence of what it is like to be a student at your school. This means while physical branding plays a part, it is important that your faculty’s personalities, and the rigorous course content your school is known for, becomes palatable online. It is essential that students feel like the same factors that make your university’s classroom learning successful go into the distance learning experience as well.  Be Outcome-Focused and Fix Student Expectations Online students have the expectation that the level of education and skills they receive in your online program are similar to those of on campus program. Online programs and courses that are designed without first establishing a lucid set of learning objectives risk lessening their effectiveness and overall value if students don’t graduate with the skills needed to achieve their goals. Make sure your program has merit by outlining desired learning outcomes for each course, then determine how they can be taught most effectively online. These are the important features to have a good online course set in a platform. WhiteHat Jr. complies with all those expectations. And even sometimes, exceeds them. Try out their free trial and check them out for your own. Have a great experience coding!

After being bullied in school repeatedly by her peers, nine-year-old Mae from Shillong, Meghalaya, developed a mobile application that allows users to report incidents of harassment to school authorities, anonymously. She was even recognised by Meghalaya Chief Minister for her innovation. Yet, with tech at the center of every human interaction today, schools have no meaningful tech curriculum at all. We set out to create the world’s first coding curriculum delivered via a live platform that connects students and teachers,” says Karan. Around 700,000 kids have registered on the portal at present, where more than 7,000 live online classes are conducted daily. Undoubtedly it's a great place to invest for the future of your kids.
